Directions
Adjust oven rack to lower third position; preheat oven to 400°F (205°C). Slice 2 carrots crosswise into 1/2-inch-thick rounds; halve remaining carrots lengthwise.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
On a rimmed baking sheet, toss all carrots with 1 tablespoon oil, 1 1/4 teaspoons salt, 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder, and 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger until evenly coated. Arrange carrot rounds and lengths in a single layer, cut side down. Roast until carrots are tender and lightly browned at edges, about 25 minutes. Let cool slightly, about 5 minutes; keep oven on.
While carrots are roasting, in a large bowl, thoroughly whisk vinegar, mustard, honey, remaining 1/2 teaspoon garlic, remaining 1/2 teaspoon ginger, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon salt. Drizzle in remaining 2 teaspoons oil while whisking constantly.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper and set aside. On a lightly floured work surface, use a rolling pin to roll puff pastry sheet into a 13- by 11-inch rectangle. Transfer to parchment-lined sheet. Using a pairing knife, lightly score a border around perimeter of puff pastry, about 1/2 inch from edges. Using a fork, prick pastry at 1-inch intervals inside the border (do not prick the border). Loosely cover with plastic wrap, and refrigerate until ready to bake.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
When ready to bake, arrange Brie slices in an even layer inside scored border of pastry. Arrange carrot rounds and lengths on top of cheese; drizzle and brush evenly with 2 tablespoons honey-mustard mixture. Lightly brush edges of pastry with beaten egg yolk.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Bake until cheese is melted and pastry is deeply browned on edges and crisp on bottom, 25 to 35 minutes. Transfer baking sheet to a wire rack and let cool 5 minutes. Transfer tart to cutting board and drizzle top with remaining honey-mustard mixture and garnish with black pepper and thyme leaves. Slice and serve warm or at room temperature.
Serious Eats / Jen Causey
Special Equipment
2 rimmed baking sheets, parchment paper
Make-Ahead and Storage
This tart is best served right after baking, but leftovers can be refrigerated for up to 3 days. To reheat, transfer to a parchment paper–lined rimmed baking sheet, cover loosely with aluminum foil, and heat in a 350°F (175°C) oven until warmed through, cheese is softened, and puff pastry is recrisped.
